prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We propose to do multiband photometry for six Narrow Line Seyfert type 1 galaxies. We mean to use standard frequencies of all six observing bands available at ALMA, using the full continuum bandwidth 7.5 GHz in dual polarization mode. We aim at minimum 20 sigma detections for each source on each band. Two of the sample sources are quite bright for ALMA (1H 0323+342 and PMN J0948+0022), while the rest (SDSS J150506.47+032630.8, SDSS J154817.92+351128.0, SDSS J162901.30+400759.9 and SDSS J164442.53+261913.2) may be below 100 mJy at high frequencies. The expected flux density levels have been calculated from the Planck Catalogue of Compact Sources for the first two sources and extrapolated to the highest bands with a spectral index derived from the PCCS data. The latter four sources do not have PCCS data. For them we used the flux density measured at Metsähovi Radio Observatory at 37 GHz and a conservative spectral index -0.4. Due to lack of data for these sources beyond low radio frequencies, the index value is purely speculative. The expected flux densities at 650 GHz are 250 mJy for the Planck-detected sources and 80 mJy for the non-Planck-detected sources.
Our aim is to obtain a full continuum radio spectrum for the sample sources. Therefore we ask for time-constrained observations in January and May 2015. The full spectrum at 6 bands should be observed for all six sources on both visits. We will coordinate our observations at Metsähovi Radio Observatory and RATAN-600 telescopes (1.1, 2.3, 4.8, 7.7, 11.2, 21.7 and 37 GHz combined) to be near-simultaneous with ALMA. Supporting observations will also be made in the optical, using the new support telescope of the MAGIC observatory in La Palma. We will observe the sample at these observatories at least twice during both January and May to ensure that the full spectrum observations are separated by no more than 2 weeks. Observations within this time frame can be thought of as simultaneous as major changes in flux are rare in smaller time scales (Hovatta et al. 2008, Nieppola et al. 2009). We are aware that in January the PWV may be quite high and obtaining 3 mJy sensitivity for high declination sources may be challenging. Fortuntely our sources have a quite favourable LST range, and the data will still be useful even with ~10 sigma detections.
The total observing time calculated by the OT is quite long, 30+ hours. Unfortunately a large part of the observing time is used on calibration and overheads, while the source integration takes typically only 2 minutes (although longer integration will be needed with higher PWV). However, at least three of our sample sources are quite close together in both R.A. and Dec: SDSS J154817.92+351128.0, SDSS J162901.30+4000759.9 and SDSS J164442.53+261913.2, though not quite filling the < 10 degree separation requirement for being in the same science goal. We leave it up to the ALMA staff to consider using the same calibration for these targets.

We propose to do multiband photometry for six Narrow Line Seyfert type 1 galaxies. We mean to use standard frequencies of all six observing bands available at ALMA, using the full continuum bandwidth 7.5 GHz in dual polarization mode. We aim at minimum 20 sigma detections for each source on each band. Two of the sample sources are quite bright for ALMA (1H 0323+342 and PMN J0948+0022), while the rest (SDSS J150506.47+032630.8, SDSS J154817.92+351128.0, SDSS J162901.30+400759.9 and SDSS J164442.53+261913.2) may be below 100 mJy at high frequencies. The expected flux density levels have been calculated from the Planck Catalogue of Compact Sources for the first two sources and extrapolated to the highest bands with a spectral index derived from the PCCS data. The latter four sources do not have PCCS data. For them we used the flux density measured at Metsähovi Radio Observatory at 37 GHz and a conservative spectral index -0.4. Due to lack of data for these sources beyond low radio frequencies, the index value is purely speculative. The expected flux densities at 650 GHz are 250 mJy for the Planck-detected sources and 80 mJy for the non-Planck-detected sources.
Our aim is to obtain a full continuum radio spectrum for the sample sources. Therefore we ask for time-constrained observations in January and May 2015. The full spectrum at 6 bands should be observed for all six sources on both visits. We will coordinate our observations at Metsähovi Radio Observatory and RATAN-600 telescopes (1.1, 2.3, 4.8, 7.7, 11.2, 21.7 and 37 GHz combined) to be near-simultaneous with ALMA. Supporting observations will also be made in the optical, using the new support telescope of the MAGIC observatory in La Palma. We will observe the sample at these observatories at least twice during both January and May to ensure that the full spectrum observations are separated by no more than 2 weeks. Observations within this time frame can be thought of as simultaneous as major changes in flux are rare in smaller time scales (Hovatta et al. 2008, Nieppola et al. 2009). We are aware that in January the PWV may be quite high and obtaining 3 mJy sensitivity for high declination sources may be challenging. Fortuntely our sources have a quite favourable LST range, and the data will still be useful even with ~10 sigma detections.
The total observing time calculated by the OT is quite long, 30+ hours. Unfortunately a large part of the observing time is used on calibration and overheads, while the source integration takes typically only 2 minutes (although longer integration will be needed with higher PWV). However, at least three of our sample sources are quite close together in both R.A. and Dec: SDSS J154817.92+351128.0, SDSS J162901.30+4000759.9 and SDSS J164442.53+261913.2, though not quite filling the < 10 degree separation requirement for being in the same science goal. We leave it up to the ALMA staff to consider using the same calibration for these targets.

However, at least three of our sample sources are quite close together in both R.A. and Dec: SDSS J154817.92+351128.0, SDSS J162901.30+4000759.9 and SDSS J164442.53+261913.2, though not quite filling the < 10 degree separation requirement for being in the same science goal. We leave it up to the ALMA staff to consider using the same calibration for these targets.

We propose to do multiband photometry for six Narrow Line Seyfert type 1 galaxies. We mean to use standard frequencies of all six observing bands available at ALMA, using the full continuum bandwidth 7.5 GHz in dual polarization mode. We aim at minimum 20 sigma detections for each source on each band. Two of the sample sources are quite bright for ALMA (1H 0323+342 and PMN J0948+0022), while the rest (SDSS J150506.47+032630.8, SDSS J154817.92+351128.0, SDSS J162901.30+400759.9 and SDSS J164442.53+261913.2) may be below 100 mJy at high frequencies. The expected flux density levels have been calculated from the Planck Catalogue of Compact Sources for the first two sources and extrapolated to the highest bands with a spectral index derived from the PCCS data. The latter four sources do not have PCCS data. For them we used the flux density measured at Metsähovi Radio Observatory at 37 GHz and a conservative spectral index -0.4. Due to lack of data for these sources beyond low radio frequencies, the index value is purely speculative. The expected flux densities at 650 GHz are 250 mJy for the Planck-detected sources and 80 mJy for the non-Planck-detected sources.
Our aim is to obtain a full continuum radio spectrum for the sample sources. Therefore we ask for time-constrained observations in January and May 2015. The full spectrum at 6 bands should be observed for all six sources on both visits. We will coordinate our observations at Metsähovi Radio Observatory and RATAN-600 telescopes (1.1, 2.3, 4.8, 7.7, 11.2, 21.7 and 37 GHz combined) to be near-simultaneous with ALMA. Supporting observations will also be made in the optical, using the new support telescope of the MAGIC observatory in La Palma. We will observe the sample at these observatories at least twice during both January and May to ensure that the full spectrum observations are separated by no more than 2 weeks. Observations within this time frame can be thought of as simultaneous as major changes in flux are rare in smaller time scales (Hovatta et al. 2008, Nieppola et al. 2009). We are aware that in January the PWV may be quite high and obtaining 3 mJy sensitivity for high declination sources may be challenging. Fortuntely our sources have a quite favourable LST range, and the data will still be useful even with ~10 sigma detections.
The total observing time calculated by the OT is quite long, 30+ hours. Unfortunately a large part of the observing time is used on calibration and overheads, while the source integration takes typically only 2 minutes (although longer integration will be needed with higher PWV). However, at least three of our sample sources are quite close together in both R.A. and Dec: SDSS J154817.92+351128.0, SDSS J162901.30+4000759.9 and SDSS J164442.53+261913.2, though not quite filling the < 10 degree separation requirement for being in the same science goal. We leave it up to the ALMA staff to consider using the same calibration for these targets.

The total observing time calculated by the OT is quite long, 30+ hours. Unfortunately a large part of the observing time is used on calibration and overheads, while the source integration takes typically only 2 minutes (although longer integration will be needed with higher PWV). However, at least three of our sample sources are quite close together in both R.A. and Dec: SDSS J154817.92+351128.0, SDSS J162901.30+4000759.9 and SDSS J164442.53+261913.2, though not quite filling the < 10 degree separation requirement for being in the same science goal. We leave it up to the ALMA staff to consider using the same calibration for these targets.

We propose to do multiband photometry for six Narrow Line Seyfert type 1 galaxies. We mean to use standard frequencies of all six observing bands available at ALMA, using the full continuum bandwidth 7.5 GHz in dual polarization mode. We aim at minimum 20 sigma detections for each source on each band. Two of the sample sources are quite bright for ALMA (1H 0323+342 and PMN J0948+0022), while the rest (SDSS J150506.47+032630.8, SDSS J154817.92+351128.0, SDSS J162901.30+400759.9 and SDSS J164442.53+261913.2) may be below 100 mJy at high frequencies. The expected flux density levels have been calculated from the Planck Catalogue of Compact Sources for the first two sources and extrapolated to the highest bands with a spectral index derived from the PCCS data. The latter four sources do not have PCCS data. For them we used the flux density measured at Metsähovi Radio Observatory at 37 GHz and a conservative spectral index -0.4. Due to lack of data for these sources beyond low radio frequencies, the index value is purely speculative. The expected flux densities at 650 GHz are 250 mJy for the Planck-detected sources and 80 mJy for the non-Planck-detected sources.
Our aim is to obtain a full continuum radio spectrum for the sample sources. Therefore we ask for time-constrained observations in January and May 2015. The full spectrum at 6 bands should be observed for all six sources on both visits. We will coordinate our observations at Metsähovi Radio Observatory and RATAN-600 telescopes (1.1, 2.3, 4.8, 7.7, 11.2, 21.7 and 37 GHz combined) to be near-simultaneous with ALMA. Supporting observations will also be made in the optical, using the new support telescope of the MAGIC observatory in La Palma. We will observe the sample at these observatories at least twice during both January and May to ensure that the full spectrum observations are separated by no more than 2 weeks. Observations within this time frame can be thought of as simultaneous as major changes in flux are rare in smaller time scales (Hovatta et al. 2008, Nieppola et al. 2009). We are aware that in January the PWV may be quite high and obtaining 3 mJy sensitivity for high declination sources may be challenging. However, at least three of our sample sources are quite close together in both R.A. and Dec: SDSS J154817.92+351128.0, SDSS J162901.30+4000759.9 and SDSS J164442.53+261913.2, though not quite filling the < 10 degree separation requirement for being in the same science goal. We leave it up to the ALMA staff to consider using the same calibration for these targets.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Narrow Line Seyfert 1 galaxies (NLS1) are active galactic nuclei with relatively low luminosities. Recently five of them have been detected in gamma-rays, and it has been established that at least some of them generate relativistic jets. Yet there are many aspects of them that remain obscure, such as the main engine of the energy production and their parent population. We propose to use ALMA to measure the continuum radio spectrum of six Narrow Line Seyfert 1 galaxies, near-simultaneously with RATAN-600 and Metsähovi radio telescopes and supporting optical observations at La Palma. Combining the data we will be able to construct virtually simultaneous spectra from 1.1 to 650 GHz at 13 radio frequencies. This unprecedented data set will be modelled numerically to look for clues of the energy production mechanisms at work, as well as compare the radio emission properties of gamma-ray detected vs. non-detected sources.
